{{Use New Zealand English|date=November 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = Bret McKenzie | image = Bret McKenzie Muppets Most Wanted Premiere (cropped).jpg | caption = McKenzie at the ''Muppets Most Wanted'' premiere on 11 March 2014 | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Bret Peter Tarrant McKenzie | alias = Rhymenoceros | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1976|6|29}} | birth_place = [[Wellington]], [[New Zealand]] | instrument = {{flatlist| * Guitar * [[Keyboard music|keyboard]] * bass guitar * drums * vocals * [[ukulele]]}} | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Comedy music|Comedy]] * [[Folk music|folk]] * [[Acoustic music|acoustic]]}} | occupation = Musician, comedian, actor
| years_active = 1994â€“present | label = [[Sub Pop]] | associated_acts = {{flatlist| * [[Jemaine Clement]] * [[Flight of the Conchords]] * [[Wellington International Ukulele Orchestra]] * [[The Black Seeds]] * [[So You're a Man]] * Video Kid * [[The Muppets]]}}
| website = | current_members = | past_members = }} '''Bret Peter Tarrant McKenzie''', [[New Zealand Order of Merit|ONZM]] (born 29 June 1976) is an Oscar and Grammy winning New Zealand comedian, actor, musician and producer. He is one half of musical comedy duo [[Flight of the Conchords]] along with [[Jemaine Clement]]. The duo's comedy and music became the basis of a [[Flight of the Conchords (radio series)|BBC radio series]] and then an oft-lauded [[Flight of the Conchords (TV series)|American television series]], which aired for two seasons on [[HBO]]. McKenzie served as music supervisor for two [[The Muppets|Muppet]] films, ''[[The Muppets (film)|The Muppets]] ''(2011) and ''[[Muppets Most Wanted]] ''(2014), the former of which won him an [[Academy Award for Best Original Song]] for the song "[[Man or Muppet]]". His latest work has seen him write the lyrics to the 2016 [[Sainsburys]] Christmas advert featuring [[James Corden]] on vocals. <ref> https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/london-life/sainsbury-s-christmas-advert-2016-5-things-you-need-to-know-about-the-greatest-gift-a3393691.html</ref>
As an actor, he portrayed [[Lindir]] in [[Peter Jackson]]'s [[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|''The Lord of the Rings'']] and [[The Hobbit (film series)|''The Hobbit'']] film trilogies, respectively: in the first he remained unnamed with fans naming him [[Figwit]], a character originally cast as an extra who gained attention thanks to the trilogy's [[Fandom|fan community]], and in ''The Hobbit'' is credited as [[Lindir]], a small character who originally appears in the book of ''[[The Fellowship of the Ring]]''.
==Background== McKenzie was born in [[Wellington]], [[New Zealand]]. He is a former member of [[The Black Seeds]]. He released an album called ''Prototype'' as Video Kid<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.videokid.tv/ |title=Video Kid}}</ref> and is a member of the [[Wellington International Ukulele Orchestra]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ukulele.co.nz |title=Wellington International Ukulele Orchestra}}</ref> McKenzie attended Clifton Terrace Model School ("model" refers to a standard school for training teachers as opposed to [[model (person)|modelling]]), [[Wellington College (New Zealand)|Wellington College]] and then [[Victoria University of Wellington]] where he met [[Jemaine Clement]] who was also studying film and theatre. Together, they were members of [[So You're a Man]] and they later formed Flight of the Conchords.
As Flight of the Conchords they have toured internationally and released four CDs: ''[[Folk the World Tour]]'' in 2002,''[[The Distant Future]]'' (which won the [[Grammy Award for Best Comedy Album]]) in 2007, the Grammy nominated ''[[Flight of the Conchords (album)|Flight of the Conchords]]'' in 2008, and ''[[I Told You I Was Freaky]]'' in 2009. The Conchords produced a six-part improvisational comedy radio program for the [[BBC]] and have appeared on ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' and ''[[The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson]]''. After a successful appearance in 2005 on [[Home Box Office|HBO]]s ''[[One Night Stand (US TV series)|One Night Stand]]'', the Conchords were offered their own 12-part HBO series ''[[Flight of the Conchords (TV series)|Flight of the Conchords]]''. Its first season ran from June to September 2007, and its second season premiered on HBO 18 January 2009.
McKenzie has appeared in the first and third films in [[Peter Jackson]]'s ''[[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|The Lord of the Rings]]'' trilogy. His silent role in the first film as [[Figwit]] achieved some minor internet fame, which led to Jackson giving him a line in the third film. In April 2011, McKenzie was cast as the elf [[Lindir]] for ''[[The Hobbit (film series)|The Hobbit]]''. His father [[Peter McKenzie (actor)|Peter McKenzie]] played the role of [[Elendil]] in ''Lord of the Rings''.
Along with Clement, McKenzie was featured as one of 2008's "100 Sexiest People" in a special edition of the Australian magazine [[Who (magazine)|''Who'']].
McKenzie and fellow Conchord Clement guest starred as a pair of camp counselors in "[[Elementary School Musical (The Simpsons)|Elementary School Musical]]", the season premiere of the [[The Simpsons (season 22)|22nd]] season of ''[[The Simpsons]]'', which aired on 26 September 2010.<ref name="Simpsons">{{Cite web|title=Gleeful over Glee: Cory Monteith to appear on The Simpsons|author=Strachan, Alex|url=http://www.canada.com/Gleeful+over+Glee+Cory+Monteith+appear+Simpsons/3350970/story.html|publisher=[[Canada.com]]|date=2 August 2010|accessdate=2010-08-02|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111028000202/http://www2.canada.com/gleeful+over+glee+cory+monteith+appear+simpsons/3350970/story.html|archivedate=28 October 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
During the summer of 2010, McKenzie flew to Los Angeles to serve as the music supervisor for [[The Muppets (film)|''The Muppets'']].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/film/4442796/Conchords-star-flies-south-for-new-film|title=Conchords star flies south|work=Stuff|accessdate=15 October 2014}}</ref> He went on to write four of the five original songs from the film's soundtrack including "Man or Muppet" and "Life's a Happy Song" both of which were nominated for [[Broadcast Film Critics Association Awards]] and [[Satellite Awards]] for Best Original Song.<ref>[[Satellite Award for Best Original Song]]</ref>
At the [[84th Academy Awards]] in 2012 his song, "[[Man or Muppet]]", won the [[Academy Award for Best Original Song]].
McKenzie, together with Australian comedian [[Hamish Blake]] starred in a New Zealand feature film, ''[[Two Little Boys (film)|Two Little Boys]]'', finished in late 2011 and released in New Zealand on March 2012.<ref name="DailyTelegraphAust_09Dec2010_SydneyConfidential_HamishBlaketostarwithBretMcKenzieinSarkies'TwoLittleBoys">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/hamish-blake-to-star-with-bret-mckenzie-in-sarkies-two-little-boys/story-e6frewz0-1225968460210|title=Hamish Blake to star with Bret McKenzie in Sarkies' Two Little Boys |last=Catanzariti|first=Katelyn|date=9 December 2010|work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)]]|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|accessdate=9 December 2010}}</ref>
McKenzie wrote the original songs for the 2014 movie ''[[Muppets Most Wanted]]''.
==Personal life== He is married to New Zealand publicist Hannah Clarke<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=10562875 | title=Bride of the Conchord - Bret marries childhood sweetheart| work=New Zealand Herald | date=22 March 2009 | accessdate=2009-05-21 | first=Rebecca | last=Lewis}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/2278386/Conchord-has-wings-clipped|title=Conchord has wings clipped|publisher=[[Fairfax New Zealand]]|date=20 March 2009|accessdate=2009-05-17}}</ref> and currently maintains residences in [[Los Angeles]], [[New York City]], and [[Wellington]]. They have two children; daughter Vita (born 2009), and son Leo (born 2011).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/music/news/article.cfm?c_id=264&objectid=10607282 |title=Fatherhood keeps 'Conchords' stars busy |work=New Zealand Herald |date=5 November 2009 |accessdate=2009-11-08 |first=Jacqueline |last=Smith}}</ref>
